page.title: 08The Local Sand Industry
page.content: Sand has been quarried around Leighton Buzzard regularly since about 1579. The canal & the railway have played a great part in transporting goods, but now road transport is used. Sand was dug by hand until the 1930s, but now work is mechanised. The sand boom came in the Great War when quarries were told to double their capacity. Leighton Buzzard sand is a high quality sharp & silica sand & the British Standard Specification is based on a Heath & Reach pit's samples. The sand contains 99% pure silica & there are 70 different shades round here. Sand is excavated by mechanical digger, mixed with water & pumped into a tower. The water drains through overnight,runs away & the sand is left in the tower. Then lorries come & take it. An exhausted pit must be filled with 14ft of water.
